summary: An unlikely friendship develops between a wealthy quadriplegic (François Cluzet) and his caretaker (Omar Sy), just released from prison.

reviews.content: The two main characters make for a great dynamic duo, while different in almost every way they share just enough personality and values to hit it off. I was surprised the movie is based on actual events as it's so dramatically structured – props to the screenwriters. The film works because of its authenticity in both the characters' environments and their corresponding quirks and worldviews. For such a serious subject matter, the movie manages to be both funny and uplifting.
Heartwarming lovely film with a lot of humour

Word of advice: skip The Upside, a sloppy American remake, and check out the original, the French film The Intouchables.  When Philippe (Francois Cluzet), a wealthy quadriplegic in need of a personal assistance, hires Driss (Omar Sy), an ex-con struggling to get by after being released from prison, an unusual friendship is formed.  While it borders on being overly sentimental, it somehow manages to never cross the line.  The relationship between the two disparate men evolves naturally and feels genuine throughout, thanks to great performances from the two leads and a script that effectively taps into the themes of redemption and acceptance.  Filled with humor and more than its fair share of poignancy, it is one of those films that is truly difficult to dislike.

Amazing movie about two completely different people with two completely different personalities and from two completely different backgrounds, yet they still able to connect emotionally and form an unusual, but still amazing friendship, where they help each other in different ways. It's also a movie about disabilities and how life can suck for those who struggle in everyday life in so many ways. Very moving film, better grab some tissues!

The Intouchables is a decently handled story about the friendship between a quadriplegic and his caregiver, but it's lack of depth and originality leads to forgettability and at times- boredom. The humour and levity in The Intouchables is quite good, the dynamic and dialogue between the energetic caretaker, Driss, and his witty but ailing partner Philippe is enjoyable and real, but the film does not have much to offer beyond their relationship. Virtually every character in the film is a caricature, Philippe is the uptight french nobleman who needs a little fun in his life, and Driss the loose and refreshing outsider who's here to shake things up, beyond that, the film's attempt to humanize the characters is both limited and often falls flat. There's even a woman (minor spoilers) who Driss pursues, despite being repeatedly rebuffed, throughout the film, and at the very end it's revealed that the reason she rejects him is because she's a lesbian. That's it. Her entire character throughout a 2 hour long movie summed up in three words. There's no setup, no conflict, no backstory, no depth between her or anyone else. It's just rejection, rejection, rejection, 'Oh I'm a lesbian' - and fade to black. Even the pair of protagonists gets boring halfway through the film because their relationship never changes, there is zero conflict between them, every moment they are together they are happy and smiling and accepting, despite there being multiple points where I expected someone to get angry, or outraged at another for crossing the line, nothing happens. That's the core problem of The Intouchables, there's no deeper meaning, there's no originality, there's nothing in the film that pushes you to make you feel, to make you think, even though it has the perfect story to do so.

Though flawed and full of cliches, The Intouchables highlights the strength of the cast and bolsters some great humor and emotion. It’s a tad long and stumbles a bit along the way, but it’s definitely worth seeing if you enjoy a good character study

Intouchables is a wonderful film that talks about an improbable but beautiful friendship, where the character Philippe, a wealthy quadriplegic and his assistant Magalie make an interview with candidates to choose their caregiver. One of the candidates, Driss, is only there to prove with a signature that he was interviewed and rejected and thus continue to receive his social security benefits. Driss is instructed to return the next day to retrieve his signed document, but when he returns he is told that he has received a job as a caregiver. Despite the lack of experience and not wanting the job, Driss takes good care of Philippe and accompanies him in everything, starting a beautiful friendship. However, a friend of Philippe warns him about Driss's criminal record, accused of theft, but Philippe doesn't care about Driss's past because he is the only one who doesn't treat him with pity, he even makes funny jokes throughout the film with the limitations that Philippe has ... transforming what was supposed to be sad into something light. The film has strong scenes, of great commotion, in addition to drawing attention, correctly, to the situation of a person with a lot of money, but who did not have friends, loves and happy moments. The film makes us conclude that having a lot of money is not synonymous with happiness.The film makes us conclude that having a lot of money is not synonymous with happiness, that the past can be left behind and that differences in class, color and race should not overlap relationships.

Rocky moments aside, the experience never feels wasted and the final scene with a magnificent Einaudi piece makes everything worth the trouble.

A few problems that I had involved the romance-related subplots. There are a juvenile level's worth of sexual references that clash with such a family-friendly tone occupying the rest of the film. The running gag of Driss trying to have sex with Audrey Fleurot's character is tired and similarly out of place. However, the dancing scene to Earth, Wind, and Fire, along with the opera scene and many other funny moments, balance out the missteps well.

The Intouchables is a buddy comedy featuring Omar Sy and Francois Cluzet playing, respectively, Driss, a Senagalese ex-con and Philippe, a wealthy paraplegic. After Driss shows up at an interview Philippe is holding for a new caretaker in an attempt to get someone to sign his welfare benefit papers to prove he's been looking for a job, Phillippe hires him on a whim, despite Driss having zero qualifications for the job and having zero actual interest in getting hired.

Omar Sy is magnetic, and his chemistry with co-lead Francois Cluzet is excellent, but their performances are dragged down by a script full of tired tropes and problematic situations played off for laughs. Especially cringeworthy was Sy's Driss repeatedly hitting on Audrey Fleurot's character, Magalie, getting turned down and not taking the hint. When it's finally revealed why Magalie isn't interested and Driss backs off, we all breathe a little sigh of relief for her. 

The problems with the script are numerous - the fore mentioned repeated sexual harassment in the workplace, a grown man bullying a child being played off for laughs, the lead fitting the "magical negro" trope to a T, the disabled character not being played by a disabled actor - but I found myself able to largely push this aside and enjoy the performances of the two lead actors as I watched the film, and came away from it hungry for more Omar Sy performances. Luckily for me, there's an entire season of Sy vehicle Lupin waiting for me on Netflix.

Reviewers have got this one so wrong, 75% is a disgrace. I think that in order to love this film you have to understand that the juxtaposition of the upright aristocratic life in contrast with the more low brow slums works to demonstrate that one man with nothing can bring more positivity than those with privilege hanging out their arses. Most people who review this film will no doubt fall into the latter and not understand the fundamental humanistic quality that this film achieves, probably because a lot of people have forgotten what being humane means.

Philippe (François Cluzet), a wealthy quadriplegic who owns a luxurious hôtel particulier, and his assistant Magalie are interviewing candidates to be his live-in caregiver. Driss (Omar Sy), a candidate, has no ambitions to get hired. He is just there to get a signature on a document showing he was interviewed and rejected so that he can continue receiving his welfare benefits. He is told to come back the next morning to collect his signed document. The next day, Driss returns and is greeted by Yvonne, Philippe's aide, who tells him that he has been given the job of live-in caregiver on a trial basis. Despite being uninterested in the job and his lack of professional experience, Driss does well in caring for Philippe, even if his methods are sometimes unconventional. Driss learns the extent of Philippe's disability and accompanies Philippe in every moment of his life, assisting him in all the ways needed. A friend of Philippe's reveals Driss's criminal record which includes six months in jail for robbery. Philippe disregards the warnings, stating he does not care about Driss's past because he is the only one that does not treat him with pity. He says he will not fire him as long as he does his job properly...

Rotten Tomatoes consensus states, "It handles its potentially prickly subject matter with kid gloves, but Intouchables gets by thanks to its strong cast and some remarkably sensitive direction." The film divided critics in the UK. Upon the film's 21 September 2012 UK release under the title Untouchable, The Independent called it "a third-rate buddy movie that hardly understands its own condescension....Why has the world flipped for this movie? Maybe it's the fantasy it spins on racial/social/ cultural mores, much as Driving Miss Daisy did 20-odd years ago – uptight rich white employer learns to love through black employee's life-force. That was set in the segregationist America of the 1940s. What's this film's excuse?" Robbie Collin of The Telegraph called it "as broad, accessible and trombonishly unsubtle as a subtitled Driving Miss Daisy"; according to Collin, the "characters are conduits for charisma rather than great dramatic roles, but the horseplay between Sy and Cluzet is often very funny, and one joke bounces merrily into the next." Nigel Farndale, also of The Telegraph, said: "The film, which is about to be released in Britain, has been breaking box-office records in France and Germany, and one of the reasons seems to be that it gives the audience permission to laugh with, not at, people with disabilities, and see their lives as they have never seen them before."

The Intouchables is about a rich man who is a quadriplegic, who hires an unlikely candidate to be his primary care-giver. I enjoyed the relationship dynamic between these two men, and how they learned to enjoy one-another’s company. They have such diverse personalities and yet because they have become so dependent on each other, they find common ground. The actors do a truly great job at portraying the journey they are taking emotionally, which is impressive considering they both seem somewhat closed off from their emotions. François Cluzet has the difficult task of making sure he doesn’t cheat and make movements that are impossible for someone in his condition. It’s one of those performances that is so convincing you completely forget that this is an actor who could stand up and walk around in real life. Omar Sy has that kind of charisma that you just want to be friends with him and hang out, so he is tailor-made for his role. As with many films that are based on a true story, The Intouchables can get a bit predictable and cliché. We kind of know where they’re going in some of the key moments, because it wouldn’t have been a story worth telling if the two men broke ties and never saw each other again. I liked some of the subplots, because those often had more unexpected outcomes that I couldn’t predict. The big danger in a story like this one is that it could fall into schmaltz, and overdo it with sentimentality. I think they reined that in well, and made an honest film that didn’t go out of its way to manipulate the audience emotionally. That’s not to say there were no emotional moments, because I certainly teared up once or twice. I also laughed many times with the characters, because they share some humorous moments, and I love how Driss speaks so honestly about the pretentious things in Philippe’s world. The Intouchables is a good film that I quite enjoyed, even if it wasn’t quite unique enough to become a favorite for me.

The Intouchables

The Intouchables is a character driven feature about a poised handicapped middle aged man that gets a fresher perspective in his life after he hires a living-the-life-to-the-full young man to take care of him. The structure of the premise is simple and familiar to the audience with an appealing details of the characteristics of the characters and the analysis of the relationship among them, which fortunately in here is in plethora of it. 

The chemistry between the lead cast is the heart of the feature that keeps the audience tangled in its sensitive bubble despite of having ups and downs. It also is flawed and cheesy at times that shucks away the somewhat credibility it gains with tiny genuinely moving notions. It is short on technical aspects like background score, cinematography, sound department and editing although the camera work is appreciative as it manually handled that offers the viewers the aspiring personal experience. 

As mentioned earlier, Cluzet and Sy has invested all their chips in, and it pays more than well enough to keep the audience rooting for their friendship. As much as compelling the storytelling is, in its primary track, the rest of the plot and characters are left undercooked and chalky that aches you till the last frame of the feature. 

Ticking for almost two hours, it easily stretches its way down the road to offer a moot and expected point with a familiar zeal that actually ignited the whole concept. The husbandry gags that are imputed in order to make the relationship more rich that enhances it to a more sensible ground and the gripping screenplay that enfolds guilty pleasures for the viewers are the high points of the feature. 

The Intouchables may not be accurately titled if considered its existence, that is more physical than spiritual, contrary to what makers claims it to be.

The Intouchables' story could be familiar to anybody, even to those who haven't seen a lot of movies. Almost every phase, and every point in this movie is so conventional and unoriginal. However, this movie is very remarkable! That's because it surpasses all the feel-good movies of its kind.

Needless to mention the high-class direction from Olivier Nakache and Eric Toledano that made this movie exceptional. Thanks to this superb direction, The Intouchables delivers broad laughs and tugs at the heartstrings without delving too deep, or present anything new. Sometimes the movie becomes so hilarious, and other times you couldn't help shedding some tears, often, of joy! The best thing about this movie that it kept its lighter tone throughout its runtime. The tonal shift when the movie moves from its second to its third act wasn't smooth, though. That being said, you will never find any movie of this kind that has half its magical moments.

The friendship between Philippe and Driss is simply unparalleled. That's, of course, due to the insanely magnetic chemistry between Omar Sy and François Cluzet. I bet you can find such chemistry in any other movie of the same kind.

The soundtrack is perfectly utilized to match the movie's bright tone. And the cinematography is beautiful, but what I think made the movie looks spectacular is its fancy production design.

The third act is definitely a bit rushed but I feel like the ending more than makes up for it. This ending could be the sweetest and most charming ending ever. You couldn't decide if you should cry or laugh, but don't worry because you would do both.

(8/10)
